snippet.title: Iron in Drinking Water
snippet.description: Iron can be a troublesome chemical in water supplies. Making up at least 5 percent of the earth's crust, iron is one of the earth's most plentiful resources.

snippet.description: Both iron and manganese are readily apparent in drinking water supplies. Both impart a strong metallic taste to the water and both cause staining. Water coming ...

snippet.title: Iron in Well Water \- EH: Minnesota Department of Health
snippet.description: Iron gives the hemoglobin of blood it's red color and allows the blood to carry oxygen. The iron in a metal pail turns to rust when exposed to water and oxygen.
